questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents with left leg swelling and pain for 5 days and has a positive D-dimer test. Duplex ultrasonography confirms an extensive DVT involving the left popliteal and femoral veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management strategy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) LMWH followed by oral anticoagulant Explanation: Treatment of DVT: Anticoagulation: For initial management of acute DVT without contraindications to anticoagulation, the current recommended approach is to start with LMWH and transition to an oral anticoagulant. This approach has several advantages: LMWH provides rapid anticoagulation without the need for monitoring. Oral anticoagulants have shown non-inferiority or superiority to warfarin in large clinical trials. They have a better safety profile and do not require regular INR monitoring. This regimen allows for outpatient management in many cases, reducing hospitalization rates. Investigation of DVT: Venous Doppler with Duplex scanning Non-invasive; detects thrombus by impaired blood flow and inability to compress veins. Presence of echogenic material completely filling the lumen of vein Absence of compressibility Absence of blood flow Venogram Accurate for detecting and locating thrombus and differentiating occlusive and non-occlusive thrombus but less commonly used due to invasiveness. Impedance Plethysmography Measures changes in venous volume and flow using a cuff. Less useful for calf DVT and previous thrombosis. Fibrin and Fibrinogen Assays Measures fibrin degradation products, including D-dimer. D-dimer has a high negative predictive value. Radioactive Fibrinogen Study Uses radiolabeled fibrinogen to detect thrombus. Less commonly used. Magnetic Resonance Venous Imaging (MRVI) Non-invasive; Useful for imaging iliac veins and IVC. Management of DVT : Initial Anticoagulation Subcutaneous LMWH: Rapidly anticoagulate confirmed DVT cases. Intravenous Unfractionated Heparin: For patients with significant renal impairment. Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin: Alternatives for those with heparin sensitivity or heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Transition to Oral Anticoagulation Duration: At least 3 months or longer based on risk factors or recurrence. Novel anticoagulants (NOACs): Rivaroxaban, Apixaban (factor Xa inhibitors), Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor). Vitamin K Antagonists: Warfarin (alternative to NOACs). Monitoring Anticoagulation

questions.question: An infant presents with a large, rapidly growing vascular malformation, along with severe thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Kasabach-Merritt Syndrome Explanation: Syndromes associated with AV Malformation: Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome Kasabach-Merritt Syndrome (KMS) A mesodermal abnormality characterized by: Cutaneous nevus, Persistent vestigial veins with varicose veins, Soft-tissue and bone hypertrophy. (Option A) Segments of deep veins are hypoplastic or aplastic. Possible obstruction of lymphatics. Treatment: Conservative management with compression stockings. Removal of large superficial varicose veins done only if deep veins are patent. A life-threatening coagulopathy of infancy characterized by: Thrombocytopenia Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia Consumptive coagulopathy. (Option B) Rapidly growing vascular tumor Treatment: Mainly supportive care Embolization: Possible if a single feeding vessel is present. Medical Therapies: Steroids,vincristine and sirolimus. Capillary hemangioma: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (Option C) is characterized by facial nevus or port wine stain and neurological symptoms like contralateral hemiparesis, focal seizures and/or intellectual disability. It is not associated with severe thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. Capillary Hemangioma (Option D) is the commonest birthmark seen on the head and neck. Majority occurs as a consequence of intravascular thrombosis, fibrosis, and mast cell infiltration and resolve spontaneously. It is not associated with severe thrombocytopenia and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

questions.question: A 50-year-old man presents with prominent varicose veins on his medial thigh and calf. Upon examination, incompetence of the great saphenous vein (GSV) is identified. The surgeon is considering the appropriate surgical intervention. What is the primary indication for performing Saphenofemoral Junction Ligation and GSV Stripping?

options.A: Varicose veins on the posterolateral calf due to small saphenous vein incompetence
options.B: Incompetence of the great saphenous vein with varicose veins on the medial thigh and calf
options.C: Varicose veins on the anterior thigh due to incompetent perforator veins
options.D: Small varicose veins unsuitable for endovenous ablation

questions.explanation: thigh and calf Correct Answer: B) Incompetence of the great saphenous vein with varicose veins on the medial thigh and calf Explanation: Incompetence of the great saphenous vein with varicose veins on the medial thigh and calf: Saphenofemoral Junction Ligation and GSV Stripping are indicated primarily for varicose veins resulting from GSV incompetence, particularly when these veins are located on the medial thigh and calf. Open Surgery Procedure Saphenofemoral Junction Ligation and Great Saphenous Vein Stripping Indication: Used for varicose veins in the medial thigh and calf due to great saphenous vein (GSV) incompetence. (Option B) (Option C ruled out) Procedure: An incision is made in the groin to access the saphenofemoral junction where the GSV meets the femoral vein. Tributaries of the GSV are ligated. Stripping: The GSV is tied off at the junction, and a device is inserted into the GSV and pulled out through an incision near the knee, stripping the vein as it is removed. Saphenopopliteal Junction Ligation and Small Saphenous Vein Stripping Indication: Used for varicose veins on the posterolateral calf due to small saphenous vein (SSV) incompetence. (Option A ruled out) Procedure: An incision is made to access and ligate the saphenopopliteal junction where the SSV joins the popliteal vein. Stripping: Similar to the GSV procedure, the surgeon either strips the vein using a device or resects the proximal portion of the vein.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male with chronic venous insufficiency presents with a venous ulcer on his lower leg. He has a history of prolonged standing at work and reports aching and heaviness in his legs. What is correct regarding compression therapy in this patient?

options.A: Class 1 compression hosiery exerts 18-24 mmHg of pressure
options.B: Compression bandaging typically exerts less pressure than compression hosiery
options.C: Compression bandaging should be avoided in patients with a history of venous ulcers
options.D: Compression therapy is most effective when it exerts a graduated pressure to promote venous return

questions.explanation: promote venous return Correct Answer: D) Compression therapy is most effective when it exerts a graduated pressure to promote venous return. Explanation: Compression therapy works by exerting graduated external pressure on the legs, which helps promote blood flow back to the heart and reduces venous hypertension. This is particularly important in conditions like varicose veins where venous return is compromised. Compression Therapy in Varicose Veins Mechanism: Graduated external pressure promotes venous return. Reduces venous pressure, especially in a standing position. Types of Compression: Compression Hosiery: Knee-length or thigh-length garments. Indications: Varicose Veins: Alleviates symptoms; first-line therapy. Post-Intervention: Used after varicose vein treatments. Minimizes complications, promotes healing, and prevents recurrence. Long-term Prevention: Lifelong Class 2 stockings are recommended Categories based on pressure levels: Class Pressure (mmHg) Class 1 14–17 (Vs Option A) Class 2 18–24 Class 3 25–35 Compression Bandaging: Multi-layered approach for desired pressure. Compression bandaging applies more pressure than hosiery and is more often used in cases like venous ulcers or more severe conditions. (Vs Option B) Indications: Venous Ulcers: Essential for ulcers from venous insufficiency; use 35–40 mmHg pressure. (Vs Option C) Mixed Ulcers: Caution with arterial disease; use 30 mmHg if ABPI 0.5–0.8. Severe Arterial Compromise: Revascularization advised before bandaging if ABPI < 0.5 or ankle pressure < 60 mmHg. Components and their roles in compression bandaging: Condition ABPI Pressure (mmHg) Venous Ulcers (no arterial disease) Not Applicable 35–40 Mixed Ulcers (with arterial disease) 0.5–0.8 30 Severe Arterial Compromise <0.5 or ankle pressure < 60 mmHg Revascularization is needed before compression Post-Intervention & Recurrence Prevention: Minimizes complications post-treatment. Prevents recurrence, especially with persistent reflux or deep venous occlusion. Lifelong use of Class 2 below-knee stockings is often recommended. Benefits: Alleviates symptoms, promotes ulcer healing and prevents ulcer recurrence/new varicose veins. Limitations: Challenges with patient compliance. Risk of skin breakdown if applied incorrectly. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1033, 1041 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0102695X15001003

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the pathophysiology of varicose veins is incorrect?

options.A: Defects in the walls or valves of the veins lead to retrograde blood flow.
options.B: Inflammatory changes in walls lead to dilatation, elongation and valvular dysfunction.
options.C: The veins have a low end-diastolic volume.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The veins have a low end-diastolic volume. Explanation: The pathophysiology of varicose veins includes the development of an increased end-diastolic volume. Pathophysiology of varicose veins: An anatomic or dynamic cause leads to the damage of the valvular system. Inflammatory changes affect the walls of the valves as well. (Option A) This leads to the retrograde blood flow and pooling of blood. This causes an increase in the end-diastolic volume in the veins. The superficial (visible) and deep venous systems are affected by this, which causes their dilatation (varicosity), elongation, and even leads to secondary valvular dysfunction. (Option B) This causes an increased ambulatory venous hypertension. This is responsible for the complications of varicose veins. (Option D) Decreased amounts of elastin and an imbalance between collagen I and III suggest that the loss of the venous wall intimal architecture leads to dilation, tortuosity, and the formation of varicose veins . Dilation of superficial venous tributaries caused by increased transmission of pressure by the perforating veins: Pathophysiology: Reference: Sabiston’s Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1815, 1816

questions.question: A patient comes to the surgery OPD complaining of small swellings and a wound on his right lower leg. On clinical evaluation, he is found to have hyperpigmentation in his right leg around the ankle and lower third of the leg. He also has a healed venous ulcer and is symptomatic. According to the CEAP classification, what is the clinical stage of the disease in this case?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) C5s Explanation: According to the CEAP classification, the healed venous ulcer belongs to the C5 group, and since the patient is symptomatic, it can be classified as C5s. The CEAP (Clinical- Etiology- Anatomy- Pathology) classification for chronic venous disorders: Feature Classification For clinical classification: No signs of venous disease Telangiectasia (<1 mm) or reticular veins ( 1-3 mm dilated veins) Varicose veins (>3 mm ) Edema Pigmentation or eczema LDS or atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica Healed venous ulcer Active venous ulcer Clinical class can be further characterised as symptomatic (s), asymptomatic (a) or recurrent following previous successful treatment or healing (r), e.g. C2a, C2s, C6r. C0 C1 C2 C3 C4a C4b C4c C5 C6 For etiological classification: Congenital Primary Secondary (post-thrombotic) No venous cause identified Ec Ep Es En For anatomical classification: Superficial veins Perforator veins Deep veins No venous location identified As Ap Ad An For pathophysiological classification: Reflux Obstruction Reflux and obstruction No venous pathophysiology identified Pr Po Pr,o Pn Pigmentation/Eczema LDS Atrophic blanche Corona phlebectatica

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman with inflammatory bowel disease presents with a painful ulcer on her leg. The ulcer has a necrotic edge and a purulent base, with significant surrounding erythema. What type of ulcer is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pyoderma gangrenosum Explanation: The clinical scenario here points to pyoderma gangrenosum that is a lower limb ulcer associated with IBS. Types of Lower Limb Ulcers: Type History Location Pain Lesion Characteristics Associated Findings Ischemic/ arterial (Option D) Smoking, Intermittent claudications Distal, on dorsum of foot or toes, over bony prominences Severe, particularly at night; relieved by dependency Irregular edge; poor granulation tissue, dry necrotic base; round or punched-out with sharp demarcation; no surrounding inflammation Trophic changes of chronic ischemia, pale, hair loss, atrophic skin, cool feet; absence of pulses, prolonged capillary refill; ankle brachial index (ABI) <0.5; dependent rubor, elevation pallor Venous (Option C) Varicose veins, DVT, trauma, surgery, multiple pregnancies; aching/ swelling worse at end of day, relieved with elevation Lower third of leg ( gaiter area ); between malleolus and lower calf, majority at medial malleolus Mild; relieved by elevation Shallow, irregular/shaggy shape; granulating base; flat or steep elevation margins; fibrinous material at ulcer bed with moderate to heavy exudate; surrounding inflammation present Lipodermatofibrosis/ lipodermatosclerosis, pigmentation, edema, atrophie blanche; telangiectasia; normal capillary refill time, normal ankle brachial index (ABI) Neurotrophic (Option A) Numbness, paresthesias, burning, loss sensation in foot, Diabetes mellitus Under calluses or pressure points (e.g., plantar aspect of first or fifth MTP joint) None Punched-out, with deep sinus, variable depth partial thickness to severe involving tendon, fascia, joint capsule, or bone; surrounding inflammation present Demonstrable neuropathy, may be associated with underlying osteomyelitis Vasculitis History of primary or secondary connective tissue disease Pretibial and dorsum of foot but not always geographically limited Extremely painful Multiple, punched-out, inflamed indurated base (pathergy phenomenon); surrounding inflammation present; surrounding skin shows reticulate vascular pattern Fat necrosis/chronic panniculitis on pathology Hypertensive (local infarct) Normal pulses Lateral malleoli Severe Black necrosis; surrounding inflammation present Aka Martorell's ulcer; seen in patients with prolonged/ suboptimal controlled hypertension Pyoderma Gangrenosum (Option B) Unknown pathogenesis Develops in sites of previous trauma, around scars, donor sites used for grafting Severe Non-infective ulceration with purulent base ; well-defined, bluish, undermined borders; surrounding erythema; deep necrotic ulcer; surrounding inflammation present Seen with inflammatory bowel disease , immunodeficient states, myeloma, leukemia, Behcet's syndrome Arterial ulcer Venous ulcer Neurotrophic ulcer Pyoderma gangrenousum Pressure ulcer

questions.question: A 62-year-old man has a chronic ulcer on his leg from a burn injury sustained 12 years ago. Recently, the ulcer has developed indurated, painless, raised edges and surrounding fibrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Marjolin’s ulcer Explanation: Marjolins ulcer A Marjolin ulcer is a type of skin cancer that develops in areas of chronically damaged skin, such as old scars, burns, or non-healing wounds. It most commonly presents as squamous cell carcinoma Venous ulcer Prevalence Responsible for 85% of all chronic limb ulcers. Causes Venous disease (superficial or deep vein incompetence or obstruction) Arterial ischemic ulcer Vasculitic ulcer Traumatic ulcer Neuropathic ulcer Neoplastic ulcer Infections. Pathophysiology Old theories: Fibrin cuff theory and white cell trapping theory but these have not been confirmed. Presently: Ambulatory venous hypertension is the primary cause. Clinical Features Gaiter's Zone: Common ulcer location around and above the medial malleoli due to numerous perforators. Ulcer: Large with gently sloping edge and granulation tissue, nonhealing, tender, recurrent with secondary infections. Surrounding skin often shows thickening, inflammation, induration, pigmentation (hemosiderosis) and fibrosis . (Option A) Lipodermatosis: Chronic inflammation, fibrosis and thickening of the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the lower leg with pigmentation and a tight, contracted appearance, often with Achilles tendon contracture. Suggests severe chronic venous disease and gives a champagne bottle appearance. Investigations Duplex scan : To assess deep and superficial veins. Biopsy: For atypical ulcers or suspected malignancy (e.g., Marjolin's ulcer). Additional tests: Full blood count, blood glucose, ESR/CRP, sickle cell test, antibody screening if ulcer appears atypical. Management Compression Therapy Superficial venous ablation or surgery Bisgaard Method: Measures to reduce edema, increase venous drainage and promote ulcer healing Elevation Massage of indurated area Passive and active exercise Other Treatments: Pentoxifylline, horse chestnut extract, biological dressings, grafts and antibiotics. Complications Hemorrhage Periostitis over tibia Marjolin's Ulcer: Well-differentiated ulcer (squamous cell or basal cell carcinoma) occurring in chronic scars (e.g., burn scars, venous ulcers). Indurated, painless, non-tender ulcer with raised, everted edges and surrounding fibrosis. (Option C) Treatment: Wide local excision Infection Talipes equinovarus Disability Pressure ulcers (Option B) are the most common complication in bedridden patients or those with spinal cord injuries over bony prominences due to prolonged pressure. Marjolin's ulcer refers to a malignant transformation arising from burn scars or chronic non-healing wounds such as pressure ulcers over many years. Actinic Keratosis (Option D) are precancerous lesions that can lead to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Ill-marginated, erythematous, scaling, and rough papules or patches, often with signs of solar damage (atrophy, uneven pigmentation, telangiectasias).

questions.question: A 64-year-old woman is scheduled for the great saphenous vein (GSV) stripping to treat her varicose veins. What is the most likely nerve injury she might experience post-operatively?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Saphenous nerve Explanation: The most likely nerve to be injured during GSV varicose vein surgery is the saphenous nerve. Complications of Varicose vein surgery: Wound infections: Most common complication, reduced by prophylactic antibiotics. Recurrent Varicose Veins(10-20%): Small saphenous vein surgery>>Great saphenous vein surgery Nerve injury: Most common serious complication. Saphenous nerve injury (7%): Occurs following great saphenous vein (GSV) stripping to the knee. (Option C) Sural nerve injury (20%): Occurs following small saphenous vein (SSV) surgery. (Option A ruled out) Common peroneal nerve injury (4%): Occurs following small saphenous vein (SSV) surgery. (Option B ruled out) Venous thromboembolic complications (0.5%): Deep vein thrombosis(DVT) Thrombophlebitis Hematoma, ecchymosis, local hyperpigmentation Lymphocele Tibial nerve (Option D) is less commonly affected as it descends along the back of the thigh and popliteal fossa to the distal border of the popliteus and is not closely associated with the surgical area of the great saphenous vein (GSV). Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1038 Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page 996 Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, Page 1427

questions.question: A patient with chronic venous insufficiency presents with symptomatic varicose veins. The physician decides to use foam sclerotherapy, specifically the Tessari technique, to treat the affected veins. What is the typical ratio of sclerosant to air used in the Tessari technique for creating the foam?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1:3 Explanation: In the Tessari technique, the typical ratio of sclerosant to air is 1:3. This ratio is used to create a stable foam with a larger surface area, which improves contact with the vein walls during sclerotherapy. Sclerotherapy A sclerosing agent, typically sodium tetradecyl sulphate , is injected into the affected vein. This agent damages the vein lining, causing it to collapse and eventually be absorbed by the body. To enhance the effectiveness of the sclerosant, it is mixed with air to create a foam . This foam allows for greater contact with the vein wall and displaces blood that could inactivate the sclerosant Indications: Telangiectasias, reticular veins, and small, nonaxial varicose veins (<6 mm) visible in chronic venous disease; suitable for patients with persistent symptoms despite medical management. Aspect Tessari Technique Sclerosants Indications and Contraindications Foam Preparation Two syringes: one with sclerosant, one with air/gas (CO2) Connected via multi-way stopcock. Sclerosant to air ratio is usually 1:3 or 1:4 Repeated plunger action to create foam STS: Synthetic sodium salt with anesthetic properties Polidocanol: Synthetic polyethylene glycol, also an anesthetic. Effective for telangiectasias, reticular veins HTS: 23% hypertonic saline, osmotic agent Candidates: Asymptomatic patients and those with controlled recent or recurrent venous bleeding may undergo sclerotherapy without additional diagnostics. Contraindications: Avoid sclerotherapy during acute venous thrombosis or pregnancy. Risks : Microembolism risk Vessel Size: Suitable for veins up to 6 mm in diameter, including small, nonaxial varicose veins, reticular veins, and telangiectasias. Injection Technique Downstream injection from larger to smaller veins. Controlled foam volume to displace blood. Advantages Minimally invasive, enhanced efficacy, safety profile. Reduced volume requirement due to foam. STS: Rapid clearance in blood, effective for larger veins. Polidocanol: Decreased risk of thrombosis, suitable for smaller veins. Tessari technique

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes the difference between Dodd and Cockett surgeries?

options.A: Dodd: ligation in the thigh; Cockett: ligation in the lower leg
options.C: Dodd: targets superficial veins; Cockett: targets deep veins
options.D: Dodd: higher risk of nerve injury; Cockett: lower risk

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Dodd: Ligation in the thigh; Cockett: Ligation in the lower leg Explanation: Dodd surgery targets perforator veins in the thigh. Cockett surgery focuses on perforator veins in the lower leg. Surgery for Perforator incompetence Surgery Purpose Technique Advantages Current Relevance SEPS (Subfascial Endoscopic Perforator Vein Surgery) Treats chronic venous insufficiency by targeting incompetent perforator veins. Minimally invasive; uses an endoscope to access and clip/divide perforator veins. Less pain, shorter recovery, fewer complications. Preferred over open surgery; effective in preventing venous ulcers. Dodd Surgery Addresses incompetent perforator veins in the thigh. Open surgery ; incision made to ligate or divide thigh perforator veins (Dodd perforators). Direct access to perforator veins. Less common due to SEPS; historically significant. Cockett Surgery Targets incompetent perforator veins in the lower leg. Open surgery ; incision over the lower leg to ligate perforator veins near the medial malleolus (Cockett perforators). Direct access to lower leg perforator veins. Less common due to SEPS; historically significant.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman presents with symptomatic varicose veins. She is interested in learning about the available treatment options and their benefits. Her primary concern is to minimize recovery time and reduce post-operative pain. Which of the following surgical approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

options.A: Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous stripping
options.B: Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous stripping

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA) Explanation: Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA): EVLA is a minimally invasive procedure associated with faster recovery , less pain , and bruising compared to open surgery. It is the preferred option for patients seeking a quicker return to normal activities. Aspect Endovenous Laser Ablation (EVLA) Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) Procedure Overview Minimally invasive, uses laser energy to close incompetent veins. Gold standard and has largely replaced surgical ligation and stripping. Minimally invasive, uses radiofrequency energy to close veins Indications Treats incompetent truncal veins, often used for varicose veins Treats incompetent truncal veins, similar to EVLA Advantages High efficacy (>95% closure rate) Cost-effective Versatile (treats large and small veins) Effective for tortuous veins Standard fibers treat perforator veins High efficacy (>95% closure rate) Standardized treatment cycles Potentially reduced post-procedural pain and bruising Simplified procedural setup without laser safety protocols Applications Varicose veins Venous ulcer treatment, when combined with compression therapy Varicose veins Key Differences Laser energy used for vein ablation Requires laser safety protocols Radiofrequency energy used for vein ablation Automated energy delivery simplifies the procedure Saphenofemoral ligation and great saphenous stripping (Option A) : An open surgical procedure with longer recovery and more post-operative pain, making it less ideal for patients wanting minimal downtime. Saphenopopliteal junction ligation and small saphenous stripping (Option B) : Another open surgery, associated with increased recovery time and discomfort post-operatively. Phlebectomy as a standalone procedure (Option D) : Involves small incisions to remove veins directly, but can cause more pain and extended recovery compared to minimally invasive options.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with chronic leg pain, swelling, and visible varicose veins. A duplex ultrasound is performed to assess venous function. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding interpreting the duplex scan in this patient?

options.A: The duplex scan should be performed with the patient in a supine position
options.B: A reflux time of less than 500 milliseconds is clinically significant
options.C: Presence of perforator vein with a diameter >3.5 mm is significant
options.D: The duplex scan is primarily used to locate perforating veins

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presence of perforator vein with a diameter >3.5 mm is significant. Explanation: Duplex imaging is the preferred modality for assessing venous insufficiency. A significant finding in duplex imaging is a perforator vein with a diameter greater than 3.5 mm and a reflux time of 500 milliseconds or longer, which indicates significant perforator reflux. This finding helps guide the management of varicose veins and associated symptoms. The duplex scan should NOT be performed with the patient in a supine position to evaluate reflux. In the supine position, valves may remain open without any flow, leading to an erroneous assessment. The correct method is to perform the scan with the patient standing or in a markedly trunk-elevated position to assess valve function and reflux accurately. (Option A) A reflux time of 500 milliseconds or longer is considered clinically significant, not <500 milliseconds. This threshold helps differentiate normal venous function from pathological reflux, which can contribute to varicose vein formation and chronic venous insufficiency. (Option B) The duplex scan is not primarily used to locate perforating veins. Instead, it is used to assess venous reflux in both superficial and deep veins , identifying incompetent valves and evaluating the overall function of the venous system. While perforator veins can be visualized, the scan’s main purpose is to determine the presence and extent of reflux. (Option D) Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1817, 1818

questions.question: The following test was conducted in the clinic for a patient suffering from varicose veins. On releasing only tourniquet 3, the filling of blood was observed. What does this signify?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Cockett’s perforator incompetence Explanation: The test being done here is a multiple/three-tourniquet test. On releasing tourniquet 3, the filling of blood signifies Cockett’s perforator incompetence (ankle perforators). Multiple tourniquet test: This test is done to locate the exact perforator that is incompetent. Procedure: The patient is asked to lie in the supine position, and the limb is elevated to empty the veins. Multiple tourniquets are tied just below the locations of the perforators (one below the saphenofemoral junction, one above the knee and one below the knee), and the patient is asked to stand. The tourniquets are removed one by one from below upwards, checking each segment of the leg for filling of blood. Once the tourniquet is removed and the segment drained by a perforator shows filling, it depicts the respective perforator

questions.question: A patient with varicose veins is being examined in the surgical OPD. The Brodie-Trendelenburg I test is done for the patient, and the surgeon notices that blood is filling from above. What does this signify?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Sapheno-femoral incompetence Explanation: The Brodie-Trendelenburg test/ Trendelenburg I test is done to determine the patency of the saphenofemoral junction and hence shows a saphenofemoral incompetence if filling from above is seen. Procedure: Patient is asked to lie in the supine position. The leg is elevated, the vein is emptied by “milking,” and a tourniquet is tied just below the saphenofemoral junction. Patient is asked to stand up quickly. The tourniquet is released. Observation: When there is rapid filling of blood from above, this signifies sapheno-femoral incompetence. Valvular incompetence (Option A) is determined by the Schwartz test . It involves tapping the lower end of the saphenous vein and feeling the impulse at the saphenofemoral junction in a standing position. This confirms the long, continuous column of blood in the vein due to valvular incompetence. Perforator incompetence (Option B) is determined by the Trendelenburg test II, which is similar to test I in that the patient is asked to stand up after the same steps. However, here, the tourniquet is not released, and the filling of blood from below signifies perforator incompetence. Presence of DVT (Option D) is determined by Perthe’s test, in which the patient is asked to walk around or exercise with an elastic bandage wrapped around the legs. The development of severe cramp-like pain in the calf determines DVT. Other tests for varicose veins: Modified Perthe’s test: For DVT After elevating the limb and emptying the veins, a tourniquet is applied at the SFJ and the patient is asked to walk around for a few minutes. If the dilated veins become more prominent, it signifies deep venous obstruction. Three tourniquet test: for specific perforator Fegan’s test for perforator: On standing, the line of varicosity is marked, and then the veins are emptied in the supine position. The examiner palpates along the marked line and notices any pits or gaps in the deep fascia that signify perforator incompetence at that site. Pratt’s test for perforator: Applying pressure to the calf muscle; if it feels tense and causes pain, it may indicate acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Morrisey’s cough impulse test for SFJ incompetence: The patient is asked to turn their face away from the examiner and cough while the examiner keeps a finger at the SFJ, and an expansile cough impulse is felt. Signifies SFJ incompetence. Ian-Aird test for SFJ incompetence. Reference: SRB’s Manual of Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 223, 224. Pratt

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with left leg swelling and pain for 3 days. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a thrombus in the popliteal vein. Which of the following veins is most likely to be involved next in the progression of this DVT?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Common femoral vein Explanation: The common femoral vein is the most likely to be involved next in the progression of this deep vein thrombosis. DVT typically propagates proximally, from the calf veins through the popliteal vein and into the femoral vein . The common femoral vein is the next major deep vein in the anatomical sequence above the popliteal vein. Most DVTs (about 90%) start in the calf veins, particularly in the soleal sinuses. From there, they can propagate proximally through the popliteal and femoral veins. Anatomy of Deep Veins in Lower Limb: Foot and ankle: Deep veins accompany the dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial arteries. Calf: Three pairs of deep veins - anterior tibial, posterior tibial (Option C) , and peroneal veins. These join to form the popliteal vein behind the knee. Thigh: The popliteal vein becomes the femoral vein as it passes through the adductor canal. The great saphenous vein (a superficial vein), and the deep femoral vein drain into the femoral vein in the femoral triangle when it becomes known as the common femoral vein. Pelvis: The common femoral vein becomes the external iliac vein (Option D) , which joins with the internal iliac vein to form the common iliac vein. Abdomen: The left and right common iliac veins join to form the inferior vena cava which goes on to the right atrium. Risk Factors for DVT: Virchow's triad: Venous stasis: Immobility (e.g., prolonged bed rest, long-distance travel) Paralysis Venous obstruction (e.g., pelvic tumors) Increasing age Hypercoagulability: Genetic thrombophilias (e.g., factor V Leiden mutation, protein C or S deficiency) Acquired conditions (e.g., malignancy, pregnancy, oral contraceptives) Antiphospholipid syndrome Vessel wall injury/Endothelial injury: Trauma Surgery Chemical irritants The great saphenous vein (Option A) is a superficial vein, not part of the deep venous system. DVT primarily affects the deep veins and is less likely to involve superficial veins.

questions.question: After noticing small swellings over his legs, a 60-year-old man comes to the surgical OPD. He is a tailor by occupation and works long hours. He explains that he experiences a heaviness and aching in the legs after a long day of work but is relieved once he elevates his legs and rests. Which of the following is not a more severe sign of this disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Pedal edema Explanation: The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of varicose veins . Pedal edema is commonly seen and is not a severe sign of this disease. Clinical features of varicose veins: Unsightly appearance of tortuous veins Dull aching pain in the legs Heaviness of legs Early fatigue of the legs Pedal edema (Option D) Signs: Pruritis, telangiectasis, reticular veins, varicose veins, positive cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction. These symptoms worsen with prolonged standing and sitting and relieve on limb elevation and rest. Varicose veins: Telangiectasias and reticular veins: More severe symptoms/ complications include: Thrombophlebitis (Option A) Hyperpigmentation (due to hemosiderrin deposits) Lipodermatosclerosis (Option B) associated with eczema Ulceration (loss of epithelium) (Option C) Bleeding from attenuated vein clusters Venous neuropathy Lipodermatosclerosis, atrophic blanche and brawny edema: Hyperpigmentation and eczema:

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with visible, dilated veins on both legs. She has a history of two pregnancies and works as a retail clerk. On examination, the dilated veins are most prominent along the posterior aspect of her calves. Which of the following describes the classification of her varicose veins based on the involved venous system?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Small Saphenous Vein (SSV) system Explanation: The given anatomical description is characteristic of the Small Saphenous Vein (SSV) system as it runs at the posterior aspect of the calf . The risk factors in the above scenario suggest that this is likely a case of primary varicose veins , as opposed to secondary varicose veins that underlying conditions like deep venous thrombosis or syndromes like Klippel-Trenaunay would cause. Risk factors for varicose veins: Age: Incidence increases with age Gender: M/c in females Obesity Pregnancy and multiparity Prolonged standing or sitting Family history Previous deep vein thrombosis Hormonal factors (e.g., oral contraceptives, hormone replacement therapy) Classification based on involved veins: Great Saphenous Vein (GSV) system (Option A) typically involves the medial aspect of the leg and thigh. Small Saphenous Vein (SSV) system (Option B) involves the posterior aspect of the calf. Non-saphenous veins (Option C) include the lateral venous system. Perforator veins (Option D) connect superficial and deep veins. Classification based on cause: Primary varicose veins: These occur due to intrinsic venous wall or valvular weakness without any identifiable underlying cause. Secondary varicose veins: These develop due to an underlying condition, such as: Deep venous thrombosis (post-thrombotic syndrome) Arteriovenous fistula Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome May-Thurner syndrome Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1029 Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page 1830, 1831

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with varicose veins in her left leg. On examination, you notice dilated, tortuous veins along the posterior aspect of her calf and lateral thigh. To accurately map the incompetent veins for potential treatment, which of the following describes the most likely location of the Boyd perforator vein?

options.A: Medial ankle, posterior to the medial malleolus
options.B: Medial calf, approximately 10 cm above the medial malleolus
options.C: Lateral calf, at the junction of the middle and lower thirds
options.D: Medial knee, approximately 10 cm below the knee joint line

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Medial knee, approximately 10 cm below the knee joint line Explanation: The Boyd perforator vein , also known as the upper paratibial perforator , is typically located on the medial aspect of the leg, approximately 10 cm below the knee joint line. This perforator connects the great saphenous vein or its tributaries to the deep veins of the leg, specifically the posterior tibial veins. Superficial veins: Great Saphenous Vein (GSV): Originates from the medial marginal vein of the foot, ascends along the medial aspect of the leg and thigh, and drains into the common femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction. Small Saphenous Vein (SSV): Begins at the lateral aspect of the foot, ascends posteriorly along the calf, and typically drains into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction which then becomes the femoral vein. Perforator veins: Perforators connect the superficial and deep venous systems, allowing blood to flow from superficial to deep veins. Key perforators include: Ankle perforators: Cockett perforators (posterior tibial perforators): Three perforators located along the medial ankle and distal calf. May and Kusters perforators Calf perforators: Boyd perforator: Located approximately 10 cm below the knee joint on the medial aspect of the leg, connects the great saphenous and superficial femoral veins. Sherman perforator: Located in the mid-calf region. Thigh perforators: Dodd perforator: Located in the middle third of the medial thigh. Hunterian perforator: Located in the upper thigh, connecting the GSV to the femoral vein. Lateral perforators: Lateral calf perforators: Less clinically significant, connecting the lateral venous system to deep veins. The medial ankle, posterior to the medial malleolus, describes the Cockett perforators (Option A) , a group of three perforators located in the distal third of the leg. The medial calf, approximately 10 cm above the medial malleolus, is more consistent with the position of the middle Cockett perforator (Option B) , not the Boyd perforator. The lateral calf, at the junction of the middle and lower thirds location (Option C), does not correspond to any major named perforator vein. The lateral aspect of the calf contains smaller, less clinically significant perforators.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of tender, erythematous cord-like swellings along different superficial veins of her lower extremities over the past 3 months. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Pancreatic malignancy Explanation: This patient presents with symptoms of recurrent superficial thrombophlebitis, possibly migratory (thrombophlebitis migrans) . The recurrent nature and lack of obvious predisposing factors raise concern for an underlying systemic condition, particularly malignancy. Trousseau identified the association of migratory thrombophlebitis and malignant disease, involving the tail of the pancreas. This association, known as Trousseau's syndrome , is a classic presentation of occult pancreatic malignancy. Superficial Thrombophlebitis (STP)/ Superficial vein thrombosis Definition: STP is marked by inflammation and thrombosis of superficial veins, most often affecting the lower extremities. Frequently occurs in patients with varicose veins. Risk Factors: Includes prolonged immobility, recent surgery, trauma, obesity, and hypercoagulable states. It is associated Paraneoplastic syndrome with Adenocarcinoma of GIT - Pancreatic ca and Diffuse type of Gastric cancer Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include pain, erythema, and a palpable, tender, cord-like structure along the affected vein. The skin may be attached to the vein and later turns brown from erythematous. Diagnosis is primarily clinical but can be confirmed with duplex ultrasonography. Management Approaches: Limited STP (<5 cm, not involving the saphenofemoral junction): NSAIDs, elastic compression stockings, and mobilization. Extensive STP (>5 cm) or involvement of the great saphenous vein: Systemic anticoagulation with fondaparinux or low molecular weight heparin, typically for 45 days. STP involving the saphenofemoral junction: Full therapeutic anticoagulation, similar to deep vein thrombosis treatment. Complications: Progression to DVT (up to 18% of cases) and pulmonary embolism (up to 7% of cases). Long-term risks include post-thrombotic syndrome and chronic venous insufficiency. Prevention Strategies: Early mobilization post-surgery, use of compression stockings in high-risk patients, and prophylactic anticoagulation when indicated. While recent childbirth (Option A) is a risk factor for thrombophlebitis, it's not relevant in this case, given the patient's age and the recurrent nature of the symptoms over three months. Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) (Option B) typically affects young male smokers and involves both arteries and veins. It's less likely in this scenario compared to malignancy. Polycythemia vera (Option D) can be associated with thrombophlebitis, but the recurrent and migratory nature of the symptoms in this case is more suggestive of malignancy, particularly pancreatic cancer.

questions.question: A 20-year-old competitive swimmer presents with a 2-day history of left arm pain, swelling, and mild discoloration after intense training. Duplex ultrasound shows a thrombus in the left subclavian vein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Paget-Schrotter syndrome Explanation: Upper Extremity DVT Less common than lower extremity DVT, comprising ~5% of all DVT cases. Serious condition with a risk of pulmonary embolism in up to one-third of cases. Typically involves thrombosis of the axillary or subclavian veins. Categories Primary Idiopathic: Idiopathic upper extremity DVT Idiopathic cases warrant evaluation for occult malignancy. Paget-Schroetter syndrome (Option B) Effort induced thrombosis due to subclavian vein compression. Often seen in young athletes with repetitive upper extremity motion (e.g., swimming). Anatomic anomalies like cervical ribs or myofascial bands can cause venous compression. It may develop as a sequale of thoracic outlet syndrome Diagnosis may involve plain films to confirm thoracic outlet syndrome (as shown in the image below). Treatment: Initial thrombolysis followed by thoracic outlet decompression (first rib and scalene muscle resection). Surgical approach: Reconstruction of axillary and subclavian veins. Post-surgery: Anticoagulation for 6-12 months. Secondary: More common Due to indwelling central venous catheters, pacemakers, thrombophilia or malignant disease. Clinical Findings Unilateral swelling Pain Extremity discomfort Erythema Palpable cord Diagnosis Duplex ultrasonography Venography or magnetic resonance venography Treatment Anticoagulation therapy: Heparin or LMWH plus warfarin for at least 3 months is the mainstay of treatment. Thrombolysis does not significantly reduce long-term manifestations. Complication Recurrence Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) Thoracic outlet syndrome (Option A) can lead to Paget-Schrotter syndrome but is incorrect because the ultrasound confirmed the presence of a thrombus. Raynaud's phenomenon (Option C) causes episodic color changes in the fingers or toes in response to cold or stress, not with a thrombus in the subclavian vein. Lymphedema (Option D) results from impaired lymphatic drainage and usually develops gradually. It is less likely to occur suddenly after exercise.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman is in the post-operative ward after a cesarean section. She had no complications and gave birth to a healthy baby. Which of the following is a prophylactic step she needs to be advised to prevent deep vein thrombosis?

options.A: Early mobilization along with compression stockings

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Early mobilization along with compression stockings Explanation: The case scenario here is of an abdominopelvic surgery that needs early mobilization with compression stockings as a prophylaxis for preventing DVT. In the above scenario, the risk factor for DVT is pregnancy and immediate postpartum, along with having undergone an abdominopelvic surgery which only needs mechanical methods of prophylaxis rather than pharmacological. Risk groups for deep vein thrombosis: Older age groups (>40 yrs) Hospitalized and immobilized patients Pregnancy and the recently postpartum state Those on hormonal replacement therapy Women on oral contraceptive pills Major surgery Long haul travellers (>6hrs) With conditions like: Past venous thromboembolism Malignancies Nephrotic syndrome Varicose veins Antiphospholipid syndrome Myeloproliferative disorders Polycythemia Obesity Prophylaxis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Method of prophylaxis is either: Mechanical or pharmacological. Activation of the calf pump mechanism: Is an effective means of prophylaxis. Achieved by simply making the patient walk. Should be done within 24 or 48 hours of the surgery. Patients should never be advised tochange position from lying down into sitting in a chair position as it leads to venous pooling in the legs and is highly thrombogenic Smoking and if on any oral contraceptives, must be stopped before surgery. Pharmacological: 5000 IU of low-dose unfractionated heparin is given every 8 hours for reduction in venous thromboembolism. LMWH can be given and is a better choice as it needs no monitoring. It is the best option for moderate and high-risk patients. Dextran 70, IV 500ml during surgery and 500ml postoperatively in 24 hours can prevent DVT. Mechanical: Compression devices like compression stockings, and external pneumatic bandages can be used prophylactically during major surgeries, laparoscopic surgeries Elevation, massaging, early ambulation, and maintaining hydration are also key steps. Level of risk Suggested thromboprophylaxis options Very low-risk General or abdominopelvic surgery No specific thromboprophylaxis Early ambulation along with compression stockings (Option A) Low risk General or abdominopelvic surgery Mechanical prophylaxis Early ambulation and mechanical device (compression stockings) Moderate risk General or abdominopelvic surgery LMWH (at recommended doses) (Option B) LDUH (Option C) or mechanical prophylaxis High bleeding risk Mechanical prophylaxis Early ambulation and mechanical device( compression stockings High risk General or abdominopelvic surgery LMWH (at recommended doses), fondaparinux (Option D) , and mechanical prophylaxis High bleeding risk General or abdominopelvic surgery for cancer Mechanical thromboprophylaxis Extended-duration LMWH (4 weeks)

questions.question: A patient came with complaints of discoloration of his left leg as shown in the image. He has a history of deep vein thrombosis and has been inconsistent on medication. What is the possible diagnosis here?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Post-thrombotic leg Explanation: The scenario here points to a post-thrombotic leg due to the history of previous DVT and non-compliance to oral anticoagulants Post-thrombotic syndrome: Post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS), also called postphlebitic syndrome and venous stress disorder is a medical condition that may occur as a long-term complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Chronic venous insufficiency patients may have superficial vein incompetence with or without perforator incompetence or having previous DVT with complete obliteration or partial recanalisation with incompetence. Develop in 20% to 50% of patients after DVT. Symptoms: Leg pain Sensation of leg heaviness, pulling or fatigue Limb swelling Signs: Leg edema Redness Dusky cyanosis Perimalleolar or more extensive telangiectasia New varicose vein Stasis hyperpigmentation Lipodermatosclerosis Leg ulcer Venous gangrene (Option A): Presents with blackish discoloration, blebs and edema. Venous ulcer (Option B): Long saphenous vein perforator incompetence is often associated with venous ulcers, typically on the medial aspect of the ankle, and is often seen in long-standing varicose veins. Atrophic blanche (Option C): It is localized white atrophic skin surrounded by hyperpigmentation and dilated capillaries associated with varicose veins.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with metastatic colorectal cancer is diagnosed with an acute DVT of the left leg. He had an episode of upper GI bleed 2 days ago. His lab results show a platelet count of 40,000/ µ L and an INR of 1.8. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for preventing pulmonary embolism in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Place a retrievable IVC filter Explanation: In this case, the patient has an acute DVT with a high risk of progression to pulmonary embolism. However, he also has significant contraindications to anticoagulation: Thrombocytopenia (platelet count 40,000/ µ L) and Coagulopathy (INR 1.8). These factors make anticoagulation extremely high-risk. In such scenarios, where there is an acute proximal DVT and a contraindication to anticoagulation, placement of an IVC filter is indicated . The choice of a retrievable filter allows for potential removal once the contraindications to anticoagulation resolve (Option C). Reassessment in 3 months is appropriate to evaluate if the filter can be safely removed and anticoagulation initiated. IVC Filters: Mechanical devices designed to prevent pulmonary embolism by trapping large clots in the inferior vena cava. Indications Recurrent thromboembolism despite adequate anticoagulation Deep venous thrombosis in a patient with contraindications to anticoagulation Chronic pulmonary embolism and resultant pulmonary hypertension Complications of anticoagulation Propagating iliofemoral venous thrombus in anticoagulation Types Two main types of IVC filters: Permanent filters: Designed for lifelong use Retrievable (temporary) filters: Can be removed when no longer needed Retrievable filters offer the flexibility of removal once the risk of pulmonary embolism has decreased or anticoagulation becomes feasible. This approach helps mitigate the long-term complications associated with permanent filters. Indications of Retrievable IVC Filter Prophylactic placement in high-risk trauma patients (orthopedic, spinal cord patients) Short-term duration, contraindication to anticoagulation therapy Protection during venous thrombolytic therapy Extensive iliocaval thrombosis Complication Migration or embolization of the filter Fracture of the filter Perforation of the IVC or adjacent structures IVC thrombosis Post-thrombotic syndrome Start anticoagulation with LMWH (Option A) is incorrect due to the high bleeding risk associated with the patient's active GI bleeding, thrombocytopenia, and coagulopathy. Place a permanent IVC filter (Option B): While an IVC filter is indicated, a permanent filter is not the best choice. Retrievable filters are preferred when possible, as they allow for removal once anticoagulation becomes feasible, reducing long-term complications associated with permanent filters. Start anticoagulation with UFH (Option D): Even anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin carries a significant risk of exacerbating the patient's bleeding complications.

questions.question: A 45-year-old man with a history of colorectal cancer underwent surgery 3 weeks ago and is now presenting with complaints of left leg swelling and pain for 3 days. His left calf is 4 cm larger than the right. Using Wells' criteria for DVT, what is his pre-test probability score and risk category?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 4 points; High risk Explanation: The Modified Wells' criteria for Deep Vein Thrombosis is a clinical prediction rule used to estimate the pretest probability for DVT. It helps clinicians determine the need for further diagnostic testing. The patient scores 4 points (Option C) on the Wells' criteria, placing them in the high-risk category. Malignancy (Including treatment done within past 6 month) (1 point) Recently bedridden for >3 days or major surgery within last 4 weeks (1 point) Calf swelling > 3 cm compared to the other leg (1 point) Entire leg swollen (1 point) This scoring system, when combined with D-dimer testing, helps in the diagnostic algorithm for DVT, potentially reducing unnecessary imaging studies in low-risk patients. Modified Well’s criteria for detecting DVT: Variable Score Lower limb trauma or surgery or immobilization in a plaster cast 1 Bedridden for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1 Tenderness along the line of femoral or popliteal veins 1 Entire limb swollen 1 Calf >3 cm larger circumference than another side 10 cm below the tibial tuberosity 1 Pitting oedema 1 Dilated collateral superficial veins (not varicose veins) 1 Previous DVT 1 Malignancy (including treatment up to 6 months ago) 1 Intravenous drug abuse 3 Alternative diagnosis more likely than DVT -2 Low probability (5%) of DVT: score –2 to 0 Moderate probability (17%) of DVT: score 1 or 2 High probability (17–53%) of DVT: score >2 Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 1044, 1045

questions.question: A 52-year-old male presents with a swollen, painful left calf that developed over the past two days. He reports no history of trauma, surgery, or prolonged immobility. Physical examination reveals a warm, erythematous, and tender left calf. Which of the following clinical features is most specific for diagnosing deep vein thrombosis?

options.A: Calf pain on dorsiflexion of the foot
options.C: Pain that worsens with leg elevation
options.D: Localized tenderness along the course of the deep veins

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Localized tenderness along the course of the deep veins Explanation: Localized tenderness along the course of the deep veins is one of the most specific clinical signs of DVT. This symptom occurs due to a thrombus within the deep veins, which triggers pain when pressure is applied along the affected vein. Clinical Feature Significance 1. Localized tenderness Specific for DVT; indicates inflammation along the vein. 2. Asymmetrical calf swelling Common but not specific to DVT. 3. Erythema and warmth Suggestive of inflammation or thrombosis. 4. Pain in the affected limb Can occur with or without movement; can indicate venous obstruction. 5. Dilated superficial veins May indicate compensatory circulation due to deep venous obstruction. 6. Homans' sign Non-specific; Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with extended knee will cause tenderness in the calf. 7. Mose’s sign Painful response to gentle squeezing of the lower calf from side-to-side. 8. Neuhof's Sign Thickening and deep tenderness in the calf muscles upon palpation. 9. Phlegmasia Alba Dolens DVT of the femoral vein causes painful congestion and edema of the leg with lymphangitis, which further increases edema (white leg). 10. Phlegmasia Caerulea Dolens Extensive DVT in iliac and pelvic veins leading to a blue leg with possible venous gangrene or infarction. Pratt's sign : Applying pressure to the calf muscle; if it feels tense and causes pain, it may indicate acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Calf pain on dorsiflexion of the foot (Option A): Homans' sign is the pain or Resistance of the calf muscles to forcible dorsiflexion of the foot. It has been traditionally associated with DVT but is not specific and should not be routinely elicited due to its lack of reliability. Asymmetrical calf swelling (Option B) is a common feature of DVT but is not specific. It can be present in other conditions, such as lymphedema or muscular injuries. Pain that worsens with leg elevation (Option C) is more indicative of arterial insufficiency . In DVT, the pain may worsen with dependency due to increased venous pressure.
